Graphical abstract A series of NiO and Co3O4 supported oxide catalysts was synthesized and investigated in the acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde to biofuels production. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, N2 sorption, FTIR and Raman spectroscopy, SEM-EDS and HRTEM techniques. The influence of the catalysts mass, glycerol to butyraldehyde molar ratios, reaction temperature and presence of solvent were deeply investigated. The dispersion of Ni and Co oxides gave distinct effects on the catalytic performances of the solids with AlTi and CeMn being actives in all conditions tested. The mechanistic aspect of the reaction was investigated by density functional theory (DFT). Among the catalysts, the high acidity of the Co/CeMn and Ni/CeMn promoted the acetalization of glycerol more efficiently to produce 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane, in spite of the glycerol oligomers formation. The correlation of the structure, acidity, morphology and texture of the solids with the catalytic performance was illustrated for solventless acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde reaction. The theoretical calculations by DFT studies revealed a more favorable route to 1,3-dioxolane production. Keywords binary oxides NiO and Co3O4 acetalization glycerol theoretical calculations Introduction Glycerol is a fascinating molecule that has the inherent advantage of multifunctionality of their hydroxyl groups [1–9]. These abundant functional groups not only assist the interactions of the tri-alcohol with polar molecules in aqueous media, but also provide active sites for reactions with other hydrocarbons, especially aldehydes, ketones or alcohols through both covalent and coordinate approaches [10–13]. In recent years, the surplus of the glycerol from biodiesel production has saturated market making catalytic transformation of tri-alcohol an attractive challenge. In this sense, acetalization of glycerol with ketones or aldehydes is a viable alternative to convert glycerol into value added cyclic acetals or ketals products [1,14,15]. For instance, the acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde can produce two branched oxygen-containing compounds e.g., 5-hydroxy-2-propyl-1,3-dioxane and 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane, as shown in Fig.1 . The 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane finds application as disinfectant, flavoring agent, surfactant, fuel additive and solvent for cosmetics and low temperature heat-transfer fluid whereas 5-hydroxy-2-propyl-1,3-dioxane is used as detergent, cosmetic and also as ignition accelerator and antiknock additive, among other uses [3,16–18]. The glycerol acetalization with carbonyl compounds is a condensation reaction to produce acetals and water. Moreover, the reaction occurs in the presence of heterogeneous catalysts of different acidic nature, especially those possessing Lewis or Brønsted acid sites [14,18,19]. At present, owing to remarkable physicochemical properties, various solid catalysts, including ion-exchange resins, zeolites, silica-based mesoporous materials, supported heteropolyacids, phosphates, clay minerals, oxides and carbon-based materials have been tested in the acetalization of glycerol reactions ([1,3,13–18] and references herewith). However, most of the tested catalysts deactivate rapidly, due to the leaching of their acid sites or structural changes in the acetalization of glycerol reactions that they were evaluated [1,19]. To circumvent these drawbacks for development of high-performance catalysts in acetalization of glycerol, oxides have appropriate characteristics such as good thermal stability, recyclability and moderate to strong Lewis acidity; this allows the highest activities and product selectivities in the catalytic transformations of glycerol [20–25]. Also, studies on the use of supported metal oxides in the acetalization of glycerol have been conducted showing the benefits of reducing the acidity of the support and the dispersion of the active sites to improve the performance of the solids in the reaction [20,21]. Previous studies indicated that the modified aluminosilicates could improve the catalytic performance in the acetalization of glycerol with carbonyl compounds [1,4,12,22]. During these processes, the acidic feature of the catalysts is very important to improve the conversion, in spite the fact that the acidity presented by the solids limits the control of the desired products in the reaction. Thus, the disvantages of such solids are the lack of stability, byproduct formation and low recyclability during the reaction. Recently, Ce and Mn-based catalysts have been investigated for the acetalization of various aryl and aliphatic carbonyl compounds reactions [1,24–27]. The acid-base character of the Ce-containing catalysts with uniform active sites is of particular importance for the aforesaid acetalization reactions. However, the use of bifunctional Ce-based solids in the acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde (AG) reaction has not been reported to date. Furthermore, the lanthana and ceria have shown promising, when used as promoters or supports to carbonation of glycerol to produce glycerol carbonate, e.g., 4-hydroxymethyl-2-oxo-1,3-dioxolane [21]. The advantages of using La2O3 and CeO2 with respect to the glycerol transformations are their basic properties, which allow decreasing the acidity of the oxides to enhance the selectivity to the desired products. Nevertheless, they have never been used previously in glycerol formals i.e., 5-hydroxy-2-propyl-1,3-dioxane and 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane production from glycerol acetalization reaction. These approaches would be promising strategies for the development of highly efficient catalysts to AG with butyraldehyde reaction under very mild conditions. Therefore, binary oxides based on Al2O3-MOx (M = Ti or La) or yet, CeO2-MnOx are selected to be evaluated as potentially stable catalysts for glycerol acetalization with butyraldehyde in the current paper. The performances of these binary oxides are compared with both pure monoxides and Ni and Co supported solids. Furthermore, aluminum-based oxides have been successfully applied as either catalyst or carries for glycerol transformation reactions, but the deactivation of the solids through phase transformation and leaching of their acid sites in these reactions is proven [9,28]. Thus, doping aluminum oxide with a higher-valence metal, such as titania and lanthana to form Al2O3-MOx (M = Ti or La) or yet, CeO2-MnOx is expected to have many advantages over their pure oxides. For instance, the properties as high stability, resistance towards leaching and strong metal-support interaction are shown by the synthesized binary oxides catalysts for acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde reaction. This would be beneficial for the formation of oxygen vacancies of CeO2 and stabilization of its lattice and thereby, resulting in high performances in the title reaction. Particularly, the Co and Ni oxides may act as active sites for Al2O3-MOx or CeO2-MnOx oxides in AG reaction and thus, providing a synergy in the oxide support and consequently, enhancing their stability. As the density functional theory (DFT) calculation may afford the possibility of understanding the mechanistic considerations of the reactions, the computational investigations about the AG reaction are also studied in this work. The AG reaction mechanisms based on both experimental and simulation results have not been exploited up to now. Experimental Catalyst preparation The porous Al2O3-MOx (M = Ti or La) and CeO2-MnOx binary oxides were prepared by sol-gel method [29], with modifications. In a typical synthesis, aluminum isopropoxide (0.05 mol, Aldrich) and isopropanol (0.2 mol, Aldrich) were dissolved in 2.5 mol of distilled water under stirring at 40 °C. Subsequently, titanium isopropoxide (0.05 mol, Aldrich) was then added dropwise to the previous mixture keeping stirring for 20 min. Thereafter, the solution was submitted reflux for aging during 1 h at 60 °C and subsequently, placed in a Teflon-line autoclave at 100 °C for 36 h. After the hydrothermal treatment, the final product was filtered, washed and dried at 36 °C for 24 h. The obtained white powder was calcined in an oven at 500 °C for 1 h under flowing air, with a heating rate of 5 °C.min-1. Henceforth, the solid will be referred to as TiO2-Al2O3, being abbreviated as AlTi. The Al2O3-La2O3 catalyst was prepared in a similar fashion using respectively aluminum isopropoxide and lanthanum nitrate, as precursors. The solid was denoted as AlLa. Similarly, the CeO2-MnOx support, namely CeMn was obtained using the abovementioned procedure with the cerium ammonium nitrate and manganese nitrate as precursors. Pure monoxides such as Al2O3, La2O3, MnO2, CeO2 and TiO2 were also prepared as references, being abbreviated as Al, La, Mn, Ce and Ti, respectively. The wet impregnation method was performed, according to our previously reported protocol [9]. Briefly, an ethanolic solution of a nickel nitrate hexahydrate (10 mL Vetec) was impregnated over 1 g of the Al2O3-MOx or CeO2-MnOx supports in a rotatory evaporator to obtain a weight nominal composition 1 wt.% of the Ni precursor supported on the Al2O3-MOx and CeO2-MnOx solids. After evaporating the solvent at 60 °C, the catalyst was dried and calcined at 350 °C in air flow at a heating rate of 1 °C.min-1for 3 h to obtain the NiO/Al2O3-MOx catalyst. A similar procedure was adopted to obtain the Co3O4/Al2O3-MOx catalyst using cobalt nitrate, as precursor. These catalysts were abbreviated as Ni/AlM or Co/AlM, in which M is Ti or La. The Co3O4/CeO2-MnOx and NiO/CeO2-MnOx were prepared in a similar fashion being abbreviated as Ni/CeMn or Co/CeMn. Characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance, 18 kV (Cu-Kα emission radiation) with an operating voltage of 40 kV and a current of 40 mA. The diffraction patterns were compared to that of the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS). Nitrogen sorption experiments were conducted on the ASAP 2000 automated adsorption system. Before measurements, the samples were degassed for 12 h at 120 °C in vacuum. The total surface area was determined according to the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. Pore size distributions were obtained through Barrett–Joyner–Halenda method (BJH) method. Scanning electron images (SEM) were recorded on a FEI, Quanta 200 FEG electron microscope. The compositions of the solids were determined on the EDS system coupled to the SEM microscope at 200 kV. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy measurements were obtained with a spectrometer Vertex 70 V (Bruker) instrument, operating at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Previously, the samples were mixed to a 1 wt.% of KBr and pelletized to the measurements. The FT-IR absorption spectra of the spent samples were recorded in the 4000–400 cm−1 range. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded on a JEOL JEM 2010 F high resolution transmission microscope operating with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The spent samples were dispersed in ethanol, sonicated and allowed to evaporate the solvent. Then, the solids were suspended on a copper grid, prior to the analysis. The interplanar distances were determined through HRTEM images using the Digital Micrograph software. Raman spectroscopy measurements of both fresh and spent samples were obtained on a LabRAM 515 Horiba Scientific spectrophotometer, which was equipped with laser line of 785 nm and a CCD detector at room temperature. The laser power used was 0.5 mW. The Si at 521 cm-1 was used as reference for the measurements. Temperature programmed of ammonia desorption (TPD-NH3) experiments were performed to determine the strength and the density of the acid sites of the catalysts. The experiments were performed in a homemade apparatus. About 100 mg of the solids were placed on U-tube and then degassed under He flow at a 120 °C for 2 h. Afterwards, samples were cooled down to 100 °C then flushed with a 5% of NH3 in He. After that, the ammonia flow was replaced by helium at the same conditions for 1 h to remove the physisorbed ammonia. Subsequently, ammonia desorption was carried out gradually from 50 a 350 °C and the amount of ammonia desorbed was recorded. Acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde Catalytic reaction of acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde was accomplished initially in the presence of toluene, as solvent. The reaction mixture was placed in batch reactor fitted with a reflux condenser and a thermostatic bath. About 140 mg of the catalyst was added to the reactor in the presence of an equimolar amount glycerol and 0.03 mol butyraldehyde with 5 mL of toluene at 50 °C. DFT studies DFT calculations were performed to determine the possible mechanistic pathways for the AG with butyraldehyde reaction using the Gaussian 09 package. The molecular visualization program GaussView was implemented in Gaussian 09 code to evaluate the transition states (TS) structure from the relaxed potential energy scans (PES). Also, the energies using DFT method were obtained through the m062x/6-311+(d,p) level. The Berny algorithm was adopted to optimize the molecule structure. In addition, low total energy for molecule structure was used to eliminate the systematic errors and obtain better agreement with the lower conformers. The following steps consist of using a series of relaxed potential energy scans (PES) to obtain a reasonable mechanism for the reaction. The relatives energies of the species present in the individual steps were obtained from the PES to determine the energy activation. Results and discussion Characterizations of the fresh catalysts Structural characterizations by XRD and Raman Fig.2 a depicts the XRD pattern of the supported solids studied. XRD patterns of the Co/AlTi and Ni/AlTi catalysts (Fig.2a) reveal the predominance of the monoclinic TiO2 anatase phase belonging to the I41/amd space group (JCPDS 71-1169). Some traces of tetragonal TiO2 rutile coming from the P42/mnm space group are also found (JCPDS 75‐1757). It is reasonable that both TiO2 rutile and anatase phases may coexist, as the calcination of the solids is performed at 500 °C. This is in line with literature reports that illustrate the irreversible TiO2 anatase transformation into TiO2 rutile takes place at temperatures ranging from 550-1000 °C [32,33]. Also, a semi-crystalline structure is shown with diffraction peaks at 2θ angles equal to 38.0 (311), 45.5 (400), and 66.8° (440) for γ-Al2O3. Moreover, the γ-Al2O3 belongs to the Fd-3m space group with a cubic structure. For Co/AlTi, some peaks could be an indicative of the spinel Co3O4, which corresponds to JCPDS card 43-1003. In the case of Ni/AlTi, discrete peaks of cubic NiO appear at 2θ = 36.9 (111), 42.8 (200), 63.1 (311) and 75.4° (222), in accordance with the JCPDS card 47-1049. Because of the amounts of NiO and Co3O4 are too low that is to say, beyond the XRD limit of detection, it is proposed that these species are well dispersed on solid surface. XRD patterns of Ni/CeMn and Co/CeMn samples (Fig. 2a) exhibit all the characteristic reflection peaks of cubic fluorite CeO2 phase with the main peaks at 2θ angles of 28.3 (111), 33.1 (200), 47.7 (220), 56.5 (111), 69.3 (220) and 76.5º (310) planes, in accordance with JCPDS 34-0394. In addition, the broadness of the peaks confirms that these solids are not well crystallized. Although the relatively narrow size of the diffractions peaks of nanocrystalline MnOx e.g., α-Mn2O3 and α-MnO2 phases do not allow distinguishing the aforesaid phases, it can be suggested that they are superimposed to those of CeO2. Furthermore, few peaks of NiO and Co3O4 phases could be detected, which indicate the dispersion of these phases on CeMn support. In the case of AlLa-based solids, the γ-Al2O3 corresponding to the Fd-3m space group is the only phase found, according to the JCPDS 10–425 file. This suggests that the NiO and Co3O4 species are well dispersed on solid surface. Additionally, it is difficult to determine the crystal sizes of the solids due to their weak intensity lines of NiO and Co3O4 phases. Complementary data about the assignations of the phases determined by XRD are obtained from Raman spectroscopy measurements. Raman spectrum of the Ni/AlTi (Fig.2b) shows the main vibration modes at about 144 (Eg), 199 (Eg), 398 (B1g), 510 (A1g) and 642 cm-1 (Eg), all of them assigned to be from the tetragonal anatase phase belonging to D4 h 19 (I41/amd) space group of symmetry. Raman spectra of anatase are vastly documented in the literature [33–35]. A similar spectrum can be easily observed for Co/AlTi, which shows a remarkable low Raman intensity compared to that of Ni/AlTi (Fig. 2b). This implies that the nanocrystalline Co3O4 phase may have interacting strongly with the AlTi support and there is an excess of intrinsic defects in the Co/AlTi, as suggested by the literature for titanium-based samples [34,35]. The most intense mode at 144 cm-1 is due to the torsion of the O–Ti–O bonds while the A1g mode is a breathing mode of the TiO6 octahedron. It is important to note that the modes associated with the γ-Al2O3 are not observable and this is strongly related to its low crystallinity or nanometric features, as found elsewhere [34]. Due to the mentioned reasons, a mode at about 1100 cm-1 assigned to be from structural OH vacancies defects presence is obtained [34,36]. Another possible explanation to this could be the presence of either NiO or Co3O4 nanocrystals well dispersed on the supports, as latter depicted by SEM-EDS results. These results are consistent with the XRD measurements. Raman spectra of both Ni/CeMn and Co/CeMn catalysts evidence an intense mode at 465 cm−1, attributable to be from the single Raman active mode of F2g symmetry of CeO2-based cubic fluorite. The weak and broad peaks at around 600 cm−1 are due to the partial breaking of Raman active oscillation mode of F2g symmetry [34]. This is in a very good agreement with the XRD results. As comparing Ni/CeMn and Co/CeMn, a significant difference between the spectra is seen. Moreover, modes due to the MnOx related phases at around 540-620 cm-1 range may be superimposed to those of CeO2, which is attributable to the nanometric feature of the former phase in Co/CeMn. Also, vibrational modes related to the cobaltite oxide are not visible due to its good dispersion on solid surface. The same behavior is expected for NiO Raman bands at 500 and 460 cm-1 in Ni/CeMn. Raman spectra of AlLa-based supports are not registered due to the strong luminescence of aluminum and lanthanum compounds during the measurements. Morphological and textural properties The morphological features of the solids are examined by SEM-EDS. The image of Co/AlTi sample consists of agglomerates formed of small spherical particles (Fig.3 a). These particles are not uniform, in terms of their sizes. Additionally, the image shows that the surface of the solid is composed of holes with diameters of hundred of nanometers (Fig.3a). This result is consistent with the presence of micro-mesopores, as later shown by the textural properties. Furthermore, EDS mapping depicts a fully homogeneous distribution of Ti, Al and O, as expected (Fig. 3a). However, cobalt nanoparticles are not seen on solid surface, being an indication of the Co3O4 occlusion on the large pores of the solids or its low amount on solid surface. Also, the content of Co on surface is close to 1.0 wt.%, as shown in the EDS spectra. This is in agreement with XRD and Raman measurements that suggested the nanometric features of Co3O4 phase. Similarly, a plate of spherical-like particles is visible for Ni/AlTi, as demonstrated in Fig. 3a. There are some subtle differences, in terms of morphology comparing Ni/AlTi catalyst with Co/AlTi one. Accordingly, the thick plates possessing globular aggregates are seen on Ni/AlTi surface. In addition, the solid surface is composed of Ni, Ti, Al and O (Fig. 3b) with NiO nanoparticles either well dispersed on the surface of the plates or in low as amounts, as predicted by Raman and XRD measurments. Unlike the spherical particles, Co/CeMn is formed of aggregated particles, some of them exhibiting pores (Fig.3b). Besides, the Ce, Mn and O elements have a homogeneous distribution on solid surface with Co3O4 phase most probably located on the surface (Fig.3b). The Ni/CeMn has a morphologyy similar to that of Co/CeMn, which depicts agglomerates of irregular shape particles on a plate surface. Most importantly, SEM image shows that these particles are formed by NiO attachment to the plates, as suggested by the EDS mapping of Ni elements (Fig. 3b). Further investigation of the textural properties by N2 isotherms analysis also reveals a porous and non-uniform surface structure. This confirms the XRD and Raman measurements, which indicates a good dispersion of nickel oxide on CeMn. In case of AlLa series, the SEM image (Fig.3c) shows uniformly distributed Co nanoparticles decorating the Co/AlLa plate support. The EDS mapping provide additional evidence of the good dispersion with Co, Al, La and O elements present in the solid. Similarly, Ni/AlLa exhibits a rough plate in which the Ni, Al, O and La elements are present (Fig.3c). Besides, the particles are agglomerated with Ni particles not uniformly distributed on the solid surface. The textural properties of the solids are obtained through the nitrogen-adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig.4 ). All isotherms are classified as type IV being characteristic of the disordered mesoporous structure, according to IUPAC classification. The solids have isotherms with comparable behaviors in the P/Po values <0.5, suggesting that they have micropores. Depending on the samples, however, distinct hysteresis loops can be observed in the higher relative pressure region. For instance, supported AlTi-based samples have a hysteresis loop between H4 and H3. This is associated with the secondary process of capillary condensation in the 0.6-1.0 P/Po range suggesting a complete filling of the mesopores [28,29]. Meanwhile, a relatively wide pore size distribution curve is observed for Ni/AlTi and Co/AlTi, in agreement with the SEM morphological features. Additionally, the AlLa binary oxides are mesoporous materials have hysteresis loop between H1 and H2. Contrary, CeMn-based samples present a H2 hysteresis behavior with the adsorption in higher relative pressure region corresponding to intraparticle or surface adsorption and condensation [19]. Besides, the pore size distribution curves of CeMn and AlTi are narrow in comparison with those of AlTi-based solids. Such large pores are presumably formed from the pore opening, when the physical absorbed water and organics precursors release these species during calcination of the solids. The textural properties obtained from the N2 isotherms are shown in Table 1 . The BET surface area varies from 109-203 m2. g-1 with the supported AlTi samples having the highest surfaces areas, compared to those of CeMn and AlLa-based ones. Also, the pore volumes of AlTi samples have higher values than those of CeMn ones. Among the supported AlTi samples, Ni/AlTi has surface area and pore volumes higher than those of Co/AlTi counterparts. This is in good agreement with the XRD, Raman and SEM morphological features that show Ni/AlTi being a low crystallized sample with 1.0 wt.% of NiO nanoparticles. These nanoparticles are indeed well dispersed on AlTi surface (SEM-EDS results) and this considerably improves the textural properties of the support. Furthermore, the pore volume of Ni/AlTi is of ca.0.46 cm3. g-1 and a decline of this parameter is observed for Co/AlTi due to the deposition of larger Co3O4 particles on the mesopores, in some extent. Correspondingly, pore size distribution for Ni/AlTi is centered at 7.4 nm while that of Co/AlTi is 9.8 nm indicating such cobalt oxide deposition on surface, in the case of the later sample. The Ni/CeMn and Co/CeMn have the lowest surface areas, smaller pore volume and reduced pore sizes rather than those of the supported AlTi-based samples. It can suggest that the morphology has an influence on the textural properties of these materials. In addition, the values BET surface area and total pore volume of supported Ni/CeMn are 109 m2,g-1 and 0.16 cm3.g-1, respectively and these values are close to those of Co/CeMn. This is an indication of the morphology modulation by the synthesis of the solids, which in turn, tunes the porous structures. Besides, the metal dispersion does not affect the porous properties of the solids being NiO or Co3O4 exclusively located on CeMn surfaces, as evidenced by SEM-EDS. The textural parameters of AlLa samples have the lowest values, among the series of solids studied. In addition, pore size distribution of Co/CeMn is a single modal centered at 4.8 nm whereas Ni/CeMn has similar features with size of ca. 6.8 nm. Thus, both solids preserve the mesoporous structures and this is a sound proof that the impregnation does not influence in the properties of the structure of the solids, when comparing with the textural parameters the supports [11,28,29]. This is in line with XRD and Raman results. On the contrary, these effects do not affect notably the surface areas in reason that smaller pores, and mesopores may be contributing significantly to the specific surface areas, as found elsewhere [19,28,29]. Catalyst screening The catalytic results of the solids in the acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde are listed in Table 2 . As it can be seen, the single monoxides have poor conversion values in 6 h of continuous AG reaction, in contrast to the binary oxide catalysts. Accordingly, the Ni, Ce, La and Co monoxides do not show activity at all. The very low acidity of these solids explains their poor activity in the AG reaction. Literature reports have shown that the Ni, Ce and Co monoxides are known to be active in the acetalization of glycerol exclusively, when they are either supported or introduced in a matrix framework [37–39]. In case of the Al, Ti and Mn monoxide catalysts, conversions levels are too low and this can be likely related to the lesser availability of their acid centers on their surfaces. In principle, glycerol transformations are strongly dependent on the acidity, which is in line with the findings for catalysts possessing γ-Al2O3, TiO2 and MnOx based oxides [40,41]. On the contrary, the binary oxides such as AlTi, AlLa and CeMn possessing acidity values inferior to 34 μmol of ammonia per gram of solid exhibit a modest catalytic activity, where conversions vary from 3.9 to 5.6%. The performance of the binary oxides in the glycerol acetalization is consistently inferior, in spite of their higher acidity compared with the monoxides. Therefore, it can be assumed that the balance between acidity and structural preservation of the phases present in the solids hold the key for the establishment of catalytic activity. This is further confirmed by the physicochemical characterizations of the spent catalysts. Important is to note that the conversion is close to 3% after 6 h of reaction time at 50 °C in the presence of toluene without using the catalysts. Thus, most of the activity of the binary AlTi and AlLa arise from the used reaction condition itself instead of the acidity of the solids. Of the catalysts studied, the metal supported catalysts display glycerol conversion up to 5.5%. It seems that the conversion increase is due to the quite available density of the acid sites. On the other hand, the dependence of the metal dispersion on the activity may arise as a secondary factor to determine the performance of the supported solids. For example, Ni/CeMn possessing 27 μmolNH3. g-1 exhibits a glycerol conversion of 61%. Contrary to the expected, in this instance, a glycerol conversion of ca. 44% is noted for Co/CeMn catalyst holding 29 μmolNH3. g-1. Thus, it can be considered that the dispersion of NiO and Co3O4 may greatly increase the acidity of the solids improving their catalytic performance, as in case of Ni/CeMn and Co/CeMn. These results reveal the main noticeable difference between catalysts, other than activity, is in the nature of the support with CeMn behaving better than AlTi and AlLa, most probably in reason of the physicochemical features of the former. This is further shown by the spent catalyst characterizations. In the case of the supported AlTi, the Co/AlTi catalyst exhibits a higher glycerol conversion than that of Ni/AlTi counterparts. Thus, it is therefore believed that the acidity of ca. 93 μmolNH3. g-1 of Co/AlTi represents the highest acidity among the solids studied. This results in a good catalytic performance of the solid in the AG reaction. Alternatives to decrease the acidity of the aluminum-based solids are also explored with adding lanthanum as in AlLa catalyst for AG reaction (Table 2). Among them, the Co/AlLa, holding the acidity of ca 24 μmolNH3. g-1 appears to be the less active catalyst with Ni/AlLa following the same trends. These solids exhibited indeed the lowest conversions among the supported catalysts, which could be attributed to basic properties of lanthanum. Comparing the versatile role of the metal dispersed, a not straightforward relation can be done with the catalytic performance because of the presence of the support. As the conversions levels for both monoxides and unsupported binary oxides are too low, TOF was not calculated. In contrast, considering that the active sites of the supported oxides consist of NiO or Co3O4, their contribution towards activity is considered to determine the TOF. Thus, the TOF shows similar tendency in the increasing of the glycerol conversion with Ni/CeMn having the highest value of ca.29 h-1. This can be associated with the porosity and high acidity, resulting in the highest catalytic performances in the targeted AG reaction, as later shown by the spent catalyst characterizations. With respect to the selectivity, the monoxides depict insignificant selectivities values due to the low conversion levels obtained. On the other hand, the binary supports produces more the five membered cyclic 1,3-dioxalane and six-membered cyclic 1,3-dioxane than their metal oxide supported catalysts counterparts. It is very hard to ascertain exact details about these results, but one can suggest that the lower conversions values of the binary supports lead to the major selectivity to the main products of the reaction. Noteworthy, the reaction between glycerol and buthyraldehyde produces cis- and trans-conformational isomers, which is in fact the total of four products from the reaction, namely cis-5-hydroxy-2-alkil-1,3-dioxane, cis-4- methanol-2-alkil-1,3-dioxolane, trans-4-methanol-2-alkil-1,3-dioxolane and trans-5-hydroxy-2-alkil-1,3-dioxane [29]. The acetalization of glycerol with carbonyl compounds reaction forms cyclic acetals including 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane, as shown in the scheme (Fig. 1). From the mechanistic point of view, glycerol reacts with the butyraldehyde forming the hemiacetal molecule and then, this intermediate molecule rearranges itself through the reaction of two of its hydroxyl groups giving the aforesaid cyclic acetals in the presence of the either Lewis or Brønsted acid sites [3,42,43]. Besides, additional reaction products such as esters of glycerol and esters of butyraldehyde are obtained in low amounts, as a result of the secondary reaction involving glycerol and butyraldehyde. Byproducts namely ‘others’ are also formed in higher amounts, in comparison with the aforesaid main product due to the occurrence of parallel reactions during the operating conditions and the moderate acidity catalyst, as well. Among the supported catalysts, the major selectivity to 1,3-dioxalane is achieved over Ni/AlLa and Co/AlLa. This may be due to the minor conversion level of these catalysts and thus, avoiding the parallel reactions. All other catalysts also exhibit the formation of the main products with cobalt-based solid being less selective to 1,3-dioxalane, as illustrated by Co/AlTi and Co/CeMn. Noteworthy, a general trend observed in terms of selectivity is that the byproducts formation (others) surpasses 51.8%, being predominant over all solids. This is the ascribed to the direct role of strong acid sites presence on the catalytic activity leads to low selectivity to the desired products, as found elsewhere [19,22]. The highest conversion of glycerol observed on supported catalysts may indicate that besides the acidity, the nature of the metal dispersed should be considered. However, the effect of the reaction conditions alone would be responsible for the catalytic activity. Thus, further experiments by varying the reaction conditions are carried out over the supported solids, regarding their superiority in the catalytic performances. Effect of the reaction time and temperature Fig.5 a depicts the conversion of glycerol as a function of the time. At the first minutes of the reaction, all catalysts exhibit very low conversion. Further increment in the reaction time results in a gradual increase of the glycerol conversion, except for Ni/AlTi. This can be attributed to the acid sites loss in 360 min of the reaction time. Among the studied supported catalysts, the best performance is achieved by Ni/CeMn. At the beginning of the reaction, the glycerol conversion rises from 37 to 61% up to the reaction time of 150 min and then, the conversion levels reaches a plateau and no further change in the conversion values is observed. Thus, the reaction time of 360 min represents the best catalytic activity for acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde reaction. Fig.5b describes the glycerol conversion in function of the time without using solvent in the reaction. Despite most of the reports indicate that the use of solvent in the acetalization/ketalization reactions is considered to be beneficial [30,44], the use of solvent as toluene may offer steric difficulties and then hampers the reactants during the AG reaction. However, the general trend observed in Fig.5b is that the solventless reaction inevitably lowers the overall catalytic performance for AlTi while the basic AlLa supported solids are inactive. On the contrary, Ni/CeMn and Co/CeMn catalysts are highly actives in the reaction and all other catalysts exhibit higher conversion values of more than 10% in 6 h of reaction (Fig.5b). The glycerol conversion values of Ni/CeMn and Co/CeMn catalysts are indeed higher, when compared to the reaction in the presence of the toluene as solvent (Fig.5a). The effect of the reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of the solids is depicted in Fig.6 . Fig.6a shows that the glycerol conversions over all solids are very low at temperatures below 50 °C with 5-hydroxy-2-propyl-1,3-dioxane selectivity staying in a narrow 10–20% range (Fig.6b). Interestingly, Co/AlTi and Ni/CeMn catalysts have distinct behaviors with the later depicting the highest glycerol conversion of ca. 60% at temperatures below 50 °C. For Ni/AlTi catalyst, the glycerol conversions are considered to be low, independently of the temperature studied due to the catalyst deactivation, as later shown by the physicochemical characterizations of the spent solids. Further increase in the reaction temperature from 50 to 70 °C greatly raises the glycerol conversions. In agreement, literature reports show elevated glycerol conversions at temperatures superior to 70 °C [4,45]. Assuming that the acetalization of glycerol with aldehyde is an equilibrium-limited acid catalyzed exothermic reaction [3,46,47], it is expected that the extent of glycerol conversion at these conditions is very limited and the catalysts used favor the mechanism of the reaction through the less energetic pathway, as later demonstrated by DFT calculations. Moreover, the influence of the temperature on the final equilibrium conversion is observed, since all solids achieve complete glycerol conversions at 90 °C. From the data in Fig.6a, the activation energy of the reaction is determined considering the process as a pseudo-first order reaction. Regarding the temperature effects, a temperature increase has influence on the final equilibrium conversion at 90 °C. Thus, the values of the activation energies are obtained in the 30-70 °C range. The activation energies calculated from equations 4 and 5 are 8.9 and 3.3 kJ.mol-1, respectively for Co/Ce-Mn and Ni/Ce-Mn catalysts. The obtained results are better than those found in the literature i.e., 55.6 kJ.mol-1 using amberlyst resin as catalysts for the acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde [29]. Besides, the selectivity to 1,3-dioxolane remains in a 5–12% range for the four catalysts at 90 °C due to the parallel reactions involving both glycerol and butyraldehyde at high temperatures. In particular, the data suggest that, at temperatures as high as 70 °C, there is a significant occurrence of side reactions leading to a large amount of byproducts with 1,3-dioxalane and 1,3-dioxane contributions being negligible. One can observe that the trends of the reaction temperature versus glycerol conversion becomes less pronounced, when operating at 50 °C with the supported Ni/CeMn and Co/CeMn catalysts holding better 1,3-dioxolane selectivity. Effect of the catalyst amount The effect of the catalysts amounts on glycerol conversions and selectivity is illustrated in Fig.7 a. The catalytic experiments were carried out by varying the amount of catalyst from 70 to 210 mg and keeping the other experimental conditions, viz., reaction time of 6 h, glycerol to butyraldehyde ratio of 1 and reaction temperature of 50 °C. These conditions are identical to those optimized in the previous sections. At very low catalyst amounts such as 70 mg, the conversion is in the 10-21% range with selectivity of 1,3-dioxolane varying from 17 to 24%. With increasing in the amount of catalyst to 140 mg, there is a gradual increase in the conversion from 7 to 61% and the selectivity to products remains constant. This is attributed to the availability of more acidic sites with rising the catalyst amounts. Additional increasing in the catalyst amount up to 210 mg provokes a decrease in the glycerol conversion but, does not change considerably the glycerol conversion keeping selectivity values invariable. The best performances are achieved using 140 mg with both conversion and selectivities slowly decreasing as the catalyst amount goes up to 140 mg at 50 °C. In this case, Ni/CeMn and Co/CeMn exhibit the best performances, among the catalysts studied. There is a not clear correlation between the catalyst type and the amount used. Thus, other relevant aspects, for example, the extent of the glycerol to butyraldehyde molar ratios still remain to be fully elucidated. Effect of the glycerol to butyraldehyde molar ratio The glycerol to butyraldehyde molar ratio is varied (Gly:But molar feed ratios of 1:1 1:2 and1:3) keeping the other experimental conditions identical to those optimize above i.e.,temperature of 50 °C and catalyst mass of 140 mg for a period of 6 h (Fig.7b). It is worthy to mention that a glycerol to butyraldehyde molar ratio to 1:3 gives the overall reaction system with conversion values in the 16-32% range. Besides, contributions of 1,3-dioxolane is nearly negligible at Gly:But molar feed ratio of 1:3 due to the fact that the glycerol is almost totally consumed. Thus, the excess of butyraldehyde leads to the dilution of substrate solution by decreasing the selectivity and favoring the production of butyraldehyde byproducts via cyclotrimerization reaction of the labile aldehyde with itself, in line with the findings [29]. When the acetalization reaction of glycerol with butyraldehyde is carried out with at Gly:But molar feed ratio of 1:2, an improvement in the glycerol conversion is observed with selectivity towards the main product values above 10%. The reason for this high conversion at Gly:But 1:2 is that the reaction still using an excess of butyraldehyde that may contribute to the 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane formation. A further increase in the Gly:But 1:1 results in high conversions and selectivity values. As it can be seen, Ni/AlTi is an exception having poor performances in all conditions evaluated. On the other hand, Ni/CeMn and Co/CeMn catalysts are chosen for further optimization of reaction parameters, in reason of their high conversion and selectivity upon the previous tested conditions. Therefore, glycerol is the limiting reagent and the best conditions for AG reaction is using a Gly:But molar feed ratios of 1:1 at 50 °C and catalyst mass of 140 mg for a period of 6 h. The catalytic results illustrate that the nature of the active sites as well as the acidity are the most important factors on catalytic performance of the solids for AG reaction. Hence, acidity and physicochemical features of the Co/CeMn and Ni/CeMn catalysts result in the formation of low amounts of the desired product e.g., 1,3-dioxolane, in spite of the majoritary by products formation (Table 1). Keeping above factors in mind, the mechanistic aspects of the glycerol acetalization reaction to demonstrate the possible routes for the desired product formation is shown in the next section Theoretical data The mechanistic aspects of the glycerol acetalization with butyraldehyde reaction are evaluated through DFT approaches. Literature reports demonstrate that two possible mechanism pathways for AG with aldehydes [1,19]. (i) In the first route, a proton from the catalyst actives the electrophilic center of the carbonyl group on the butyraldehyde by forming a carbocation; the later specie interacts with the terminal hydroxyl group of the glycerol forming the hemiacetal, as intermediate (Fig.8 ). Then, the hemiacetal is chemically adsorbed on solid surface through hydrogen bond; simultaneously, a tertiary carbocation ion is produced, being stabilized by resonance with the anti-bonding electrons adjacent to the oxygen atoms [19]. Finally, a quick attack of the nucloephillic intermediate to the secondary hydroxyl group of glycerol takes place and the hydrated adduct undergoes rearrangement to form 1,3-dioxolane with a water molecule formation [48]. (ii) In the second scenario, a nucleophilic attack of the secondary hydroxyl groups of glycerol to the butyraldehyde forms a hemiacetal intermediate; in the following step, the intermediate receives a proton from the catalyst and rearranges forming the 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane. As the carbocation ion lifetime is too short in comparison to that of the hemiacetal, the formation of the 5-hydroxy-2-propyl-1,3-dioxane is governed by the kinetics factors, which favors indeed the transition state of low energy [39,46]. The most stable structures of glycerol, butyraldehyde, 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane and 5-hydroxy-2-propyl-1,3-dioxane obtained by optimization are depicted through their HOMO and LUMO orbitals and their electron delocalization contours (Fig.9 ). As it can be seen, the fully electron deslocalization of glycerol molecule is on the O atom while the carbonyl group of butyraldehyde is electron deficient. Accordingly, the HOMO of the nucleophilic glycerol (Fig.9B) has the ability to donate electrons to the LUMO coming from electrophilic butyraldehyde (Fig.9A). Thus, the chemical interaction between glycerol and butyraldehyde reactants through electron transfer may take place in the frontier orbital. Also, the electron density of the 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane and 5-hydroxy-2-propyl-1,3-dioxane products (Fig.9 C and Fig.9 D) indicate that the route proposed in Fig.8 is likely. Noteworthy, the highest electron density of electrons on glycerol molecule suggests that the chemical reactions between glycerol and butyraldehyde can be proceed through the simplified mechanism by HOMO-LUMO interaction and thus, the hemiacetal intermediate may be formed. Moreover, the 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane is thermodynamically favored and thereby, the most favorable mechanism pathway is where 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane is mainly formed,as shown in Fig.8. The simplified mechanism pathway is summarized in Fig.8. Accordingly, the protonation of the carbonyl compound takes place due to the acid sites coming from the catalyst. Then, the hemiacetal cationic intermediate is formed, being further attacked by the nucleophilic attack of the hydroxyl molecules from the glycerol trialcohol. As a result, the interaction of glycerol and aldehyde gives a quick cyclization reaction and the reactants are subsequently converted into water and 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane. Starting from the abovementioned mechanistic considerations, the frontier orbital HOMO-LUMO chemical interactions between molecules are evaluated through the energy barrier. For these calculations, only one parameter is adjusted or yet, the surface energy is considered, when two or more parameters variables are studied. For the hemiacetal formation, a surface potential energy diagram is investigated upon adjusting one only parameter i.e, the hydroxyl group of glycerol with the central of glycerol with the protoned electrophilic butyraldehyde molecule. The initial interatomic distance of the glycerol reactant molecule is 3 Å with the reduction for 1.5 Å (Fig.10 a), when the molecules are optimized in 17 frames of 0.1 Å. These configurations allow the HOMO and LUMO overlapping to the reaction occurrence between the optimized molecules of the hemiacetal and 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane (Fig.10b). In the step of 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane formation, the parameters are adjusted for the terminal hydroxyl group of hemiacetal with the carbonyl one and the water release step. As it can be seen, both the hemiacetal and the carbonyl intermediates undergo a cyclization reaction, as represented in Fig.10b. Such a structure is further converted into the 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane, as reported on acetalization of biomass-derived molecules aldehydes [49–51]. This is the dominating mechanism for AG reaction, considering that this step occurs with greater HOMO-LUMO interactions, when compared to that of the 5-hydroxy-2-propyl-1,3-dioxane formation pathway. Elsewhere, it is cited that the strong bond of the molecules during the cyclization for 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane formation is a slow step and the thermodynamically stable 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane is formed [52,53]. Thereby, the rate-determining step may have low energy barrier with a maximum HOMO-LUMO gap [54]. As a result, it would be expected that the energy barrier could decrease in this step, but the TS1 value is slightly reduced to 45.4 kcal mol-1 (Fig.10c), which is probably lower than that of the 5-hydroxy-2-propyl-1,3-dioxane step route. Additionally, the obtained TS value is high for the non-catalyzed AG reaction and thus, the use of the catalyst provide a decrease in the energy of the transition states through an alternative route to obtain 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane, as shown by the experimental results. Thus, it is evident that the possible AG reaction mechanism involves an interaction between glycerol (R1) with butyraldehyde (R2) inherently yielding the hemiacetal intermediate (TS1) in the presence of an acid site coming from the catalyst. Subsequently, the secondary hydroxyl group of glycerol depicts a nucleophilic attack to produce 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane (P2) product along with a certain amount of water from the TS2., This is in line with the findings for acetalization of glycerol reactions [55]. Spent catalyst characterizations Attempts of justify the better performance of the solids are made by means of the spent catalysts characterization studies. The changes in the catalyst structure are demonstrated by the spent catalyst characterizations. Structural features To further investigate the physicochemical features of the catalysts after the reaction, the FTIR spectra are obtained. All spent samples have broad bands at around 3420 and 1635 cm−1 (Fig.11 ), Fig.12 being associated with the OH stretching and bending vibrations of the adsorbed water molecules, as previously reported [56]. Compared to the fresh samples, similar bands are obtained [11,29]. Furthermore, the water can be formed from AG reaction, when the Lewis metal sites coordinate and activate carbonyl group forming the hemiacetal intermediate and thus, the desired 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane product, again consistent with the proposed DFT mechanistic insights. Regarding the intensity of the FTIR bands OH groups in spent AlLa and AlTi-based catalysts, it can be suggested that water from the reaction may act bonding to the Lewis acid sites by deactivating the solids (Fig. 11a). At frequencies below 600 cm-1, the absorption bands are assigned to the typical Me-O bonds vibrations e.g., Me = Al, La, Ce, Mn, Ni or Co. Furthermore, the FTIR spectra display bands at about 1382 and 2849 cm−1, which is characteristic of symmetric and asymmetric stretching of the C-H bonds ν(CH3, CH2) such as those present in glycerol, butyraldehyde, 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane and byproducts formed, as shown previously [11]. The appearance of such broad bands and their positions in Co/AlTi and Co/AlTi indicate that these products are strongly adsorbed on Co3O4 and NiO Lewis sites, which is consistent with the low performance of these solids, comparing with the supported CeMn counterparts. It is easy to observe that the samples depict C − O stretching vibration of epoxide, C − OH groups stretching of carbonyl and carboxyl groups at around 1500 cm-1, which confirmed the presence of the byproducts. Particularly, a distinct FTIR spectrum is seen over Ni/CeMn revealing that the assistance of the NiO sites in the adsorption of butyraldehyde reactant to promote the reaction, as shown in the previous section. Raman spectra in Fig.11b display the structural feature of the solids, after the AG reaction. Raman modes located at 1047, 1183, 1347, and 1471 cm-1 appear in the AlTi-based catalysts due to the interaction between glycerol and butyraldehyde. These samples exhibit a group of weak bands where the main vibrational at 1041 cm-1 emphasizes the presence of C-H bonds deformation and the ring breathing modes as well as C-OH groups from glycerol [19]. In addition, the bands located at 1588, 1606, and 1787 cm−1 in Co/AlTi are related to the ν(C-OH) and ν(C = C) stretching vibrations from adsorbed glycerol, in agreement with the FTIR spectra. These bands are not visible in Ni/AlTi and CeMn-based samples. It is thus hypothesized that the enhancement in the catalytic performance over CeMn-based samples is mainly due to the low interaction of the glycerol and butyraldehyde reactants resulting in the AG reaction occurrence. In particular, the mode at 1180 cm-1 is due to the ν(C-OH) from a secondary carbon and a significant shoulder at wavenumber of about 1047 cm-1 is due to the τ(CH2) torsion, which assign the presence of glycerol byproducts on Ni/AlTi and Co/AlTi. Hence, the low performance of these solids compared to those of CeMn-based analogues is clearly related to the strong adsorption capacity of these samples by the byproducts instead of AG reaction. Due to the strong luminescence, Raman spectra of AlLa series are not obtained. TEM and HRTEM images HRTEM image of the spent solids reveals crystalline nanoparticles dispersed on the supports for all spent solids (Fig. 12). In the case CeMn-based samples, the particles sizes vary from 8-18 nm. For of Co/AlTi and Co /AlTi, plenty of bigger particles are attached to the surface support demonstrating that these particles sizes are roughly in the range of 10 to 30 nm (high magnification image). The aggregation of the particles after the catalytic test over AlTi-based samples does not inhibit the catalytic performance of Ni/AlTi and Co/AlTi. Indeed, the difference between them, in terms of performance appears due to the high resistance against deactivation of the Ni/AlTi. Besides, the values of the interplanar distance of 0.366 nm (101) and 0.247 nm (101) confirms that the TiO2 anatase and Al2O3 remain present in all AlTi-based catalysts, as illustrated by the high magnification images. However, the NiO and Co3O4 phases are not detected due to the leaching of these particles after the catalytic test. For Co/CeMn-based catalysts, the particles are not uniformly distributed on CeMn support having much higher amounts of big particles comparing with the Ni/CeMn counterparts. Also, d spacings values of 0.329 from (111) plane are associated with the CeO2 phase while d = 0.171 nm (101) corresponds to the NiO phase in Ni/CeMn. Moreover, an amorphous zone corresponding to the MnOx species is also found on the Co/CeMn sample but any Co particle is detected. Ultimately, leaching of these particles extremely affects the activity of Co and Ni oxide particles, which can be due to the weak interaction of these particles with the AlTi support. On the contrary, it should be noted that the CeMn support probably contribute to the stable dispersion of the Co and Ni oxide nanoparticles, even if sintering occurs after the catalytic test. Also, the high acidity of the CeMn support favors the glycerol conversion, but leads to 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane impairment with favoring the byproducts formation. Conclusions Acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde was investigated over Ni and Co oxides supported on CeMn, AlTi and AlLa. The dispersion of Ni or Co on the supports greatly improved the glycerol conversion with Ni/CeMn and Co/CeMn showing much higher performances than other solids thanks to their active sites and acidity. On the contrary, the high acidity of the Co/AlTi and Ni/AlTi catalysts resulted in low glycerol conversion and the formation of low amounts of the desired product e.g., 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane, in spite of the majoritary by products formation. The AlLa-based solids had low activity in the reaction due to their low stability during AG reaction. DFT studies suggested the most favorable reaction pathway with low energy barriers for the LUMO and HUMO interactions form the reactants molecules. The Ni/CeMn catalyst displayed superior performance in terms of conversion ca.53%, selectivity toward 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane (45%) and versatility in the presence or absence of solvents. Under the best reaction conditions (glycerol/butyraldehyde molar ratio of 1:1, reaction temperature of 50 °C and reaction time of 6 h), glycerol was converted to 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane, even if byproducts of oligomerization were formed. coredata.dc:description: A series of NiO and Co3O4 supported oxide catalysts was synthesized and investigated in the acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde to biofuels production. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, N2 sorption, FTIR and Raman spectroscopy, SEM-EDS and HRTEM techniques. The influence of the catalysts mass, glycerol to butyraldehyde molar ratios, reaction temperature and presence of solvent were deeply investigated. The dispersion of Ni and Co oxides gave distinct effects on the catalytic performances of the solids with AlTi and CeMn being actives in all conditions tested. The mechanistic aspect of the reaction was investigated by density functional theory (DFT). Among the catalysts, the high acidity of the Co/CeMn and Ni/CeMn promoted the acetalization of glycerol more efficiently to produce 4-methanol-2-propyl-1,3-dioxolane, in spite of the glycerol oligomers formation. The correlation of the structure, acidity, morphology and texture of the solids with the catalytic performance was illustrated for solventless acetalization of glycerol with butyraldehyde reaction. The theoretical calculations by DFT studies revealed a more favorable route to 1,3-dioxolane production.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic acetalization of glycerol to biofuel additives over NiO and Co3O4 supported oxide catalysts: experimental results and theoretical calculations
